Chinese imperial cuisine
is derived from a variety of cooking styles of the regions in China, mainly from the cuisines of
Shandong (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shandong_cuisine)
and
Jiangsu (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jiangsu_cuisine)
provinces. The style originated from various
Emperors (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emperor)
' Kitchen and the
Empress Dowagers (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Empress_Dowager)
' Kitchen, and it is similar to
Beijing cuisine (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beijing_cuisine)
which it heavily influenced.
Imperial cuisine was served mainly to the emperors, their
empresses (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Empress)
and concubines, and the
imperial family (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imperial_family)
. The characteristics of the Chinese imperial cuisine are the elaborate cooking methods and the strict selection of raw materials, which are often extremely expensive, rare or complicated in preparation. Visual presentation is also very important, so the colour and the shape of the dish must be carefully arranged. The most famous Chinese imperial cuisine restaurants are both located in
Beijing (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beijing)
:
Fang Shan
(
仿膳
;
fǎngshàn
) in
Beihai Park (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beihai_Park)
and
Ting Li Ting
(
聽鸝廳
;
tīng lí tīng
) in the
Summer Palace (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Summer_Palace)
.
[1] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_imperial_cuisine#cite_note-1)
Styles and tastes of Chinese imperial cuisine vary from dynasty to dynasty. Every dynasty has its own distinguishing features. The two famous styles of Chinese imperial cuisine are from the
Ming (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ming_dynasty)
and
Qing (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qing_dynasty)
dynasties. Many famous dishes emerged in these dynasties, such as Wensi tofu and
Peking duck (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peking_duck)
.
[2] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_imperial_cuisine#cite_note-china.org-2)
History
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Chinese_imperial_cuisine&action=edit&section=1)
]
Main article:
History of Chinese cuisine (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Chinese_cuisine)
See also:
List of sources of Chinese culinary history (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_sources_of_Chinese_culinary_history)
In the
history of Chinese cuisine (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Chinese_cuisine)
, Chinese imperial cuisine experienced a development process which changed from simple to exquisite. Through the changing of dynasties, Chinese imperial cuisine was continually changing, improving and self-completing. Chinese imperial food originated around the
Zhou dynasty (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zhou_dynasty)
(
c.
11th century – 476 BCE). Emperors used their power to collect best cuisines and best cooks from throughout the country. Therefore, from the Chinese people's perspective, imperial cuisine represented a dynasty's best cuisine.
[2] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_imperial_cuisine#cite_note-china.org-2)
A complete system for imperial cuisine was developed which included procurement and diets preparation. Every process of making and serving imperial cuisine was done in a fixed order according to the "eating principles". Many famous dishes were developed through creating imperial food such as the six cereals stew which included rice, millet, broomcorn, sorghum, wheat and wild rice.
[3] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_imperial_cuisine#cite_note-pre-3)
Imperial cuisine was closely related to preserving health. Several hundred writings about using food and diet therapy for better health have appeared throughout Chinese history. For example,
The Health Building of the People in the Song Dynasty
, by
Song Xu (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Song_Xu)
,
the Gentlemen's Remark on Diets
, by
Chen Jiru (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chen_Jiru)
, and
the History of the Ming Palace - Preferences for Diets
, by Liu Ruoyu in the Ming dynasty. Most of these books about diet therapy were written by scholars, literati, medical specialists or historians. Cooking and diet therapy to maintain good health formed an important part of Chinese imperial cuisine and Chinese dietetic culture.
[4] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_imperial_cuisine#cite_note-4)
Although only the imperial family was authorised to consume imperial cuisine, Chinese imperial cuisine comprised the dietetic culture of the Chinese palaces. The raw materials of imperial cuisines were provided by peasants, herders, and fisherman. The kitchen utensils were made by craftsmen. Imperial cuisine can also represent the efforts of the cooking staff who provided the service, civil officials who named the dishes, and protocol officials who drafted the dietary and culinary principles. Chinese imperial cuisine is a valuable part of Chinese traditional cuisine and cultural heritage.
[5] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_imperial_cuisine#cite_note-5)
Imperial cuisine in the Ming dynasty
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Chinese_imperial_cuisine&action=edit&section=2)
]
Imperial cuisine in the
Ming dynasty (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ming_dynasty)
was mostly cooked with the flavours of
southern China (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_China)
because of the preferences of
Zhu Yuanzhang (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hongwu_Emperor)
, the founder of the Ming dynasty.
[6] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_imperial_cuisine#cite_note-acutimes-6)
The cuisine in the Ming palace totally changed the Mongolian style of food served during the
Mongol (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mongols)
-led
Yuan dynasty (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yuan_dynasty)
. The imperial cuisine of the Ming dynasty had one important characteristic, which was to maintain good health.
[7] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_imperial_cuisine#cite_note-7)
The emperors of the Ming dynasty paid great attention to maintaining their health by eating healthy food. The menu of imperial cuisine changed daily and dishes were not repeated.
[8] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_imperial_cuisine#cite_note-china.org3-8)
Imperial cuisine of the Ming dynasty was mainly grain-based. Therefore, meat and bean products were not as popular as they were in the former dynasties. In the
Qing dynasty (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qing_dynasty)
, a famous dish was sweet potatoes. Maize and chili peppers were also introduced in around the mid-16th century. Other famous dishes including
shark's fin soup (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shark%27s_fin_soup)
and
edible bird's nest (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edible_bird%27s_nest)
also gained their fame during this period. Those two dishes were introduced to China by the explorer
Zheng He (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zheng_He)
in the early Ming dynasty. While these two dishes were becoming examples of extravagant dishes,
sea cucumbers (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sea_cucumber)
and prawns were also brought into China. Many famous cooks and chefs such as Song Wusao and Wang Eryu emerged in the Ming dynasty.
[3] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_imperial_cuisine#cite_note-pre-3)
Popular dishes
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Chinese_imperial_cuisine&action=edit&section=3)
]
Peking duck
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Chinese_imperial_cuisine&action=edit&section=4)
]
Main article:
Peking duck (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peking_duck)
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Peking_Duck_3.jpg)
Peking duck
Peking duck originated in the
Southern and Northern Dynasties (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southern_and_Northern_Dynasties)
(420–589 CE), specifically originated in Nanjing.
[9] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_imperial_cuisine#cite_note-9)
Roasted duck was first served as a dish in imperial cuisine during the
Yuan dynasty (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yuan_dynasty)
. It developed fully and became an important part of imperial cuisine menus during the Ming dynasty. In contemporary society, Peking roasted duck has entered international cuisine. Peking roasted duck was famous because of its crispy skin and the juicy meat which left a deep impression on people eating it for the first time. Since the imperial era, the dish is admired for its thin, crispy skin sliced in front of the diners by the cook.
[10] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_imperial_cuisine#cite_note-10)
There are unique techniques to serving and eating Peking duck for maximum enjoyment of its taste.
[11] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_imperial_cuisine#cite_note-11)
Imperial cuisine in the Qing dynasty
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Chinese_imperial_cuisine&action=edit&section=5)
]
Chinese imperial cuisine in the
Qing dynasty (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qing_dynasty)
was developed basing on the traditional diet of the
Manchu ethnic group (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manchu_people)
and
Shandong cuisine (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shandong_cuisine)
.
[12] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_imperial_cuisine#cite_note-Jacqueline-12)
The famous
Manchu Han Imperial Feast (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manchu_Han_Imperial_Feast)
was created during this dynasty. There was a special organisation, the Imperial Kitchen, within the Qing imperial palace which was responsible for creating and making imperial cuisine for the emperor. The Imperial Kitchen was managed by the General Office of Internal Affairs. During the reign of the
Qianlong Emperor (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qianlong_Emperor)
(
r.
1735–1796), the Imperial Kitchen was divided into the Internal Kitchen and the External Kitchen. The Internal Kitchen had departments for meat dishes, vegetables, roasting, baking and rice cooking. The External Kitchen prepared the palace banquets, feasts and sacrificial rites.
[2] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_imperial_cuisine#cite_note-china.org-2)
During the Qing dynasty, the rites for the meals, the number of people, and the use, cost, variety and quality of sumptuous courses at each meal were the greatest of all the dynasties in China.
[2] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_imperial_cuisine#cite_note-china.org-2)
Popular dishes
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Chinese_imperial_cuisine&action=edit&section=6)
]
Dezhou braised chicken
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Chinese_imperial_cuisine&action=edit&section=7)
]
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Single_Dezhou_braised_chicken_wrapped_in_paper_(20170115132902).jpg)
Dezhou braised chicken
Dezhou braised chicken (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dezhou_braised_chicken)
is a traditional dish from
Dezhou City (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dezhou)
,
Shandong Province (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shandong)
and it is named after its place of origin. When the
Qianlong Emperor (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qianlong_Emperor)
travelled to Dezhou City, a
Han Chinese (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Han_Chinese)
family made braised chicken for him. The emperor thought highly of this dish and praised it as "a wonder of all cuisine". After eating Dezhou braised chicken, the Qianlong Emperor ordered that this dish be included in the menu of imperial cuisine.
[13] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_imperial_cuisine#cite_note-chinatoday2-13)
Dezhou braised chicken features red glossy skin, tender texture, aromatic smell, and a juicy taste.
[14] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_imperial_cuisine#cite_note-14)
Wensi tofu
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Chinese_imperial_cuisine&action=edit&section=8)
]
Wensi tofu is a meal in
Jiangsu cuisine (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jiangsu_cuisine)
. It is a soup made of finely shredded
tofu (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tofu)
and different ingredients of different colours, such as
carrots (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carrot)
and
cucumbers (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cucumber)
. This dish represents the typical work of knife skill of a chef from
Yangzhou (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yangzhou)
because a chef needs to cut a square of tofu into more than 5,000 pieces in order to make this soup.
[15] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_imperial_cuisine#cite_note-15)
During the reign of the Qianlong Emperor, there was a monk by the name of Wensi, who was famous for making vegetarian dishes, particularly those with tofu. He created this soup which ingredients included tender tofu, dried
daylily (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daylily)
, and
black fungus (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wood_ear)
. This soup soon became well known throughout the region as "Wensi Tofu".
[16] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_imperial_cuisine#cite_note-16)
The Qianlong Emperor tried this soup and highly appreciated it. Wensi tofu then added by the emperor to the menu of imperial cuisine.
[17] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_imperial_cuisine#cite_note-chinatoday-17)
Styles
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Chinese_imperial_cuisine&action=edit&section=9)
]
There are currently (as of 2017) eight styles of Chinese imperial cuisines of different Chinese dynasties have been restored:
Chinese imperial cuisine of the Qin and Han dynasties (秦漢菜): Restored by Qujiangchun (曲江春) Restaurant in
Xi'an (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xi%27an)
based on records in ancient Chinese texts, including more than a dozen dishes.
[18] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_imperial_cuisine#cite_note-18)
Chinese imperial cuisine of the Tang dynasty (唐朝宮廷菜/仿唐宴): Based on
Wei Juyuan (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wei_Juyuan)
’s Shao-Wei Banquet Menu (燒尾宴食單), restaurants in Xi’an such as Tang Music Hall (唐樂宫) restored many dishes of Chinese imperial cuisine of the Tang dynasty.
[19] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_imperial_cuisine#cite_note-19)
[20] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_imperial_cuisine#cite_note-20)
[21] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_imperial_cuisine#cite_note-21)
[22] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_imperial_cuisine#cite_note-22)
Chinese imperial cuisine of the Northern
Song dynasty (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Song_dynasty)
(北宋宮廷菜/仿北宋宴): Chinese imperial cuisine of the Northern Song dynasty restored by restaurants in
Kaifeng (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kaifeng)
such as You-Yi-Xin (又一新) and Sun-Yang-Zheng-Dian (孫羊正店).
[23] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_imperial_cuisine#cite_note-23)
[24] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_imperial_cuisine#cite_note-24)
Chinese imperial cuisine of the Southern Song dynasty (南宋宮廷菜/仿南宋宴): Chinese imperial cuisine of the Southern Song dynasty restored by restaurants in
Hangzhou (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hangzhou)
such as Southern Grand Hotel of Hangzhou (杭州南方大酒家) and Hangzhou Bagua Building (杭州八卦大樓).
[25] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_imperial_cuisine#cite_note-25)
[26] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_imperial_cuisine#cite_note-26)
Chinese imperial cuisine of Dunhuang (敦煌宮廷菜/敦煌宴): Chinese imperial cuisine of Dunhuang restored by restaurants in
Dunhuang (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dunhuang)
such as Dunhuang Hotel (乾隆禦宴) and Dunhuang Villa (敦煌山莊).
[27] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_imperial_cuisine#cite_note-27)
[28] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_imperial_cuisine#cite_note-28)
Qianlong era (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qianlong_Emperor)
imperial cuisine (of the mid
Qing dynasty (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qing_dynasty)
) (乾隆御宴): Chinese imperial cuisine of the mid Qing dynasty restored by restaurants in
Yangzhou (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yangzhou)
such as Yangzhou Western Garden Grand Hotel (揚州西苑大酒店), with dished prepared according to menus of imperial banquets held by the Qianlong Emperor during his trips to southern China.
[29] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_imperial_cuisine#cite_note-29)
Chinese imperial cuisine of the late Qing dynasty (晚清宮廷菜): Chinese imperial cuisine of late Qing dynasty prepared for
Empress Dowager Cixi (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Empress_Dowager_Cixi)
. Restaurants in
Beijing (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beijing)
such as Fangshan Restaurant (仿膳飯莊) and Ting Li Ting (聽鷂廳) restaurant, and restaurants in
Shenyang (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shenyang)
such as Shenyang Imperial Cuisine Restaurant (瀋陽禦膳酒樓) restored this Chinese imperial cuisine based on menus of the imperial kitchens of the
Forbidden City (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forbidden_City)
and
Summer Palace (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Summer_Palace)
, as well other records.
[30] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_imperial_cuisine#cite_note-30)
Chinese imperial cuisine of
Chengde (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chengde_Mountain_Resort)
(塞外宫廷菜): Chinese imperial cuisine of the Qing dynasty prepared at
Chengde Mountain Resort (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chengde_Mountain_Resort)
during the emperors' annual summer trips to
Chengde (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chengde)
. This Chinese imperial cuisine differs from other styles of Chinese imperial cuisines in that the main ingredients is mostly beef, mutton and lamb, along with meat from
game (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_(hunting))
.
[31] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_imperial_cuisine#cite_note-31)

Map showing major regional cuisines of China
Shandong cuisine
(
simplified Chinese (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters)
:
山东菜
;
traditional Chinese (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters)
:
山東菜
;
pinyin (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pinyin)
:
Shāndōngcài
), more commonly known in Chinese as
Lu cuisine
, is one of the Eight Culinary Traditions of
Chinese cuisine (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_cuisine)
and one of the Four Great Traditions (
四 (https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%9B%9B)
大 (https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%A4%A7)
菜 (https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E8%8F%9C)
系 (https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%B3%BB)
). It is derived from the native cooking style of
Shandong Province (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shandong)
, a northern coastal
province (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Provinces_of_China)
of
China (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China)
.
Features
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Shandong_cuisine&action=edit&section=1)
]
Shandong cuisine is famous for its wide selection of material and use of different cooking methods. The raw materials are mainly domestic animals and birds, seafood and vegetables. The masterly cooking techniques include
bao
(爆; quick frying),
liu
(溜; quick frying with corn flour),
pa
(扒; stewing),
kao
(烤; roasting),
zhu
(煮; boiling), and coating sugar onto fruits with honey as the adhesive.
[1] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shandong_cuisine#cite_note-1)
Styles
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Shandong_cuisine&action=edit&section=2)
]
Shandong cuisine is divided into two sub-regional styles: Jinan and Jiaodong. Shandong cuisine is known for its light aroma, freshness and rich taste.
[
citation needed (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)
]
It puts emphasis on two types of broths, light and milky. Both broths are seasoned with scallions and go well with the freshness of seafood.
[
citation needed (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)
]
Jiaodong (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jiaodong)
style, encompassing dishes from eastern Shandong:
Fushan (a district of Yantai) (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fushan_District)
,
Qingdao (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qingdao)
,
Yantai (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yantai)
and the surrounding regions. It is characterised by seafood dishes with a light taste.
[
vague (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Vagueness)
]
Jinan (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jinan)
style, made up of dishes from Jinan,
Dezhou (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dezhou)
,
Tai'an (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tai%27an)
and the surrounding regions. One of its features is the use of soup.
[2] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shandong_cuisine#cite_note-Travel-2)
Influence
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Shandong_cuisine&action=edit&section=3)
]
Although less available in overseas Chinese restaurants, Shandong cuisine is considered one of the most influential schools in Chinese cuisine.
[3] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shandong_cuisine#cite_note-Imperial-3)
Modern cuisines in
North China (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_China)
(
Beijing (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beijing_cuisine)
,
Tianjin (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tianjin_cuisine)
and the
Manchuria (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northeast_China)
) are branches of Shandong cuisine, and meals in most Northern Chinese households are typically prepared using simplified Shandong methods.
[2] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shandong_cuisine#cite_note-Travel-2)
During the
Spring and Autumn period (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spring_and_Autumn_period)
(770-221 BCE), there were 2 influential states,
Qi (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qi_(state))
and
Lu (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lu_(state))
. Both states, with mountains and fertile plains, were economically and culturally developed and had abundant aquatic products, grains and sea salt. Some of the earliest known descriptions of Chinese culinary methods come from the states. Yi Ya, a retainer of
Duke Huan of Qi (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duke_Huan_of_Qi)
, was renowned for his culinary skill.
Confucius (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Confucius)
(who was born in the Lu state) was quoted in the
Analects (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Analects)
as saying, "One should not indulge overly in fine flour, or in
kuai
(a dish akin to
carpaccio (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carpaccio)
) that is sliced too thinly". About food, he recommended: "Do not consume food which looks spoiled, smells spoiled, is out of season, is improperly butchered, or is not made with its proper seasoning".
[
citation needed (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)
]
The cuisine as it is known today was created during the
Yuan dynasty (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yuan_dynasty)
. It gradually spread to northern and northeastern China. In Beijing and Tianjin, it influenced
Imperial cuisine (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_Imperial_cuisine)
. Shandong cuisine is primarily made up of
Jiaodong (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shandong_Peninsula)
and
Jinan (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jinan)
dishes.
[3] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shandong_cuisine#cite_note-Imperial-3)
Ingredients
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Shandong_cuisine&action=edit&section=4)
]
Although modern transportation has increased the availability of ingredients throughout China, Shandong cuisine remains rooted in tradition. It is noted for its variety of
seafood (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seafood)
, including
scallop (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scallop)
,
prawn and shrimp (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shrimp_and_prawn_as_food)
,
clam (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clam)
,
sea cucumber (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sea_cucumbers_as_food)
and
squid (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Squid_as_food)
.
Maize
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Shandong_cuisine&action=edit&section=5)
]
Shandong is unique for its use of
maize (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maize)
, a local
cash crop (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cash_crop)
not widely cultivated in northern China. Unlike the
sweet corn (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sweet_corn)
of North America, Shandong maize is chewy and starchy, and often has a grassy aroma. It is served as steamed (or boiled) cobs, or the kernels are removed from the cob and lightly fried.
Peanuts
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Shandong_cuisine&action=edit&section=6)
]
Shandong is noted for its peanuts, which are fragrant and naturally sweet. Large dishes of peanuts (roasted in the shell or shelled and stir-fried with salt) are common at meals, and they are served raw in a number of cold dishes from the region.
Grains
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Shandong_cuisine&action=edit&section=7)
]
Shandong uses a variety of small grains. Millet, wheat, oats and barley can be found in the local diet, often eaten as
congee (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Congee)
or milled and cooked into a variety of steamed and fried breads. People in Shandong tend to prefer steamed breads rather than rice as a staple food.
Staple vegetables
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Shandong_cuisine&action=edit&section=8)
]
Despite its agricultural output, Shandong has not traditionally used the variety of vegetables seen in southern Chinese cooking. Potatoes, tomatoes, cabbages, mushrooms, onions, garlic and eggplant are staple vegetables, with grassy greens, sea grasses and bell peppers also common. The large, sweet cabbages grown in central Shandong are known for their delicate flavour and hardiness; a staple of the winter diet in much of the province, they appear in many dishes.
[4] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shandong_cuisine#cite_note-4)
Vinegar
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Shandong_cuisine&action=edit&section=9)
]
Shandong's greatest contribution to Chinese cuisine is arguably its vinegar. Hundreds of years of experience and unique local methods have led to the region's prominence in Chinese vinegar production. Unlike the lighter, sharper types of vinegar popular in the south, Shandong vinegar has a complexity which some consider fine enough to stand alone.
[5] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shandong_cuisine#cite_note-5)

Subgroups of Shandong cuisine
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Shandong_cuisine&action=edit&section=10)
]
Jinan (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jinan)
cuisine (
济南菜
;
濟南菜
;
Jìnán cài
): The cooking methods of Jinan cuisine focus on quick frying, roasting and boiling. Jinan-style food is generally sweet, aromatic, fresh and tender. A famous dish from Jinan is stir-fried
large yellow croaker (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Larimichthys_crocea)
with sugar and vinegar (
糖醋大黄鱼
;
糖醋大黃魚
;
táng cù dàhuángyú
).
Jiaodong (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shandong_Peninsula)
cuisine (
胶东菜
;
膠東菜
;
Jiāodōng cài
): Jiaodong cuisine focuses more on cooking and cutting skills. The Jiaodong area is located close to the sea, so most raw materials are seafood. Sea cucumber, abalone and scallop are common in this area. A famous Jiaodong dish is stir-fried sea cucumber with scallions (
葱烧海参
;
蔥燒海參
;
cōng shāo háishēn
).
Kongfu cuisine (
孔府菜
;
Kǒngfǔ cài
): "Kongfu" refers to the descendants of
Kong Qiu (Confucius) (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Confucius)
. The Kong family have high standards for the quality of every dish. Therefore, for every dish, Kongfu style emphasizes rigorous slicing skills during preparation and elegance when served.
Luxinan cuisine (
鲁西南菜
;
魯西南菜
;
Lǔ xīnán cài
): "Luxinan" refers to southwestern parts of Shandong Province. Local people like foods made of natural ingredients; they occasionally flavor dishes with Chinese herbs.

Geographic extent of Sichuan cuisine
Sichuan cuisine
or
Sichuanese cuisine
,
alternatively romanized (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Postal_romanization)
as
Szechwan cuisine
or
Szechuan cuisine
(
Chinese (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_language)
:
四川 (https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/d/db/Sichuan.ogg/Sichuan.ogg.mp3)
ⓘ (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Sichuan.ogg)
,
Standard Mandarin (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Standard_Chinese)
pronunciation:
[sɨ̂.ʈʂʰwán] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:IPA/Mandarin)
[No Text] (https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/d/db/Sichuan.ogg/Sichuan.ogg.mp3)
ⓘ (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Sichuan.ogg)
)
[1] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sichuan_cuisine#cite_note-1)
is a style of
Chinese cuisine (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_cuisine)
originating from
Sichuan province (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sichuan)
and the neighboring
Chongqing municipality (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chongqing)
. Chongqing was formerly a part of Sichuan until 1997; thus, there is a great deal of cultural overlap between the two administrative divisions. There are many regional, local variations of Sichuanese cuisine within Sichuan and Chongqing.
[2] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sichuan_cuisine#cite_note-2)
It is renowned for fiery and bold tastes, particularly the pungency and spiciness resulting from liberal use of
garlic (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Garlic)
and
chilis (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chili_pepper)
, as well as the unique flavors of
Sichuan (Szechuan) pepper (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sichuan_pepper)
. Some examples are
Kung Pao chicken (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kung_Pao_chicken)
and
Yuxiang shredded pork (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yuxiang_shredded_pork)
. Four substyles of Sichuan cuisine include Chongqing,
Chengdu (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chengdu)
,
Zigong (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zigong)
(known for a genre of dishes called
yanbangcai (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yanbangcai)
), and
Buddhist vegetarian (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buddhist_vegetarianism)
style.
[3] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sichuan_cuisine#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDunlop2003[httpsarchiveorgdetailslandofplentytrea00dunl_23-24]-3)
UNESCO (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UNESCO)
declared Chengdu, the capital of Sichuan Province, a
city of gastronomy (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/City_of_Gastronomy)
in 2011.
[4] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sichuan_cuisine#cite_note-4)
History
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Sichuan_cuisine&action=edit&section=1)
]
In the
Middle Ages (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Middle_Ages)
, Sichuan welcomed
Middle Eastern (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Middle_Eastern)
crops, such as
broad beans (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Broad_beans)
,
sesame (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sesame)
and
walnuts (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walnuts)
. Since the 16th century, the list of major crops in Sichuan has even been lengthened by
New World (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_World)
newcomers. The characteristic chili pepper originally came from
Mexico (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mexico)
but probably overland from
India (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India)
or by river from
Macau (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Macau)
, complementing the traditional
Sichuan (Szechuan) peppercorns (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sichuan_peppercorn)
. Other newcomers from the New World included corn, which largely replaced
millet (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Millet)
; white potatoes introduced by
Catholic missions (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Catholic_missions)
; and sweet potatoes. The population of Sichuan was cut by perhaps three-quarters in the wars from the
Ming dynasty (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ming_dynasty)
to the
Qing dynasty (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qing_dynasty)
. Settlers from the adjacent
Hunan Province (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hunan)
brought their cooking styles with them.
[5] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sichuan_cuisine#cite_note-Anderson-5)
Sichuan is colloquially known as the "heavenly country" due to its abundance of food and natural resources. One ancient Chinese account declared that the "people of Sichuan uphold good flavors, and they are fond of hot and spicy taste." Most Sichuan dishes are spicy, although a typical meal includes nonspicy dishes to cool the palate. Sichuan cuisine is composed of seven basic tastes: sweet, sour, numbingly spicy, spicy, bitter, fragrant/aromatic, and salty. Sichuan food is divided into five different types: sumptuous banquet, ordinary banquet, popular foods, household-style food and snacks. Milder versions of Sichuan dishes remain a staple of
American Chinese cuisine (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Chinese_cuisine)
.
[6] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sichuan_cuisine#cite_note-sz-6)
[7] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sichuan_cuisine#cite_note-7)
The superior natural resources of
Sichuan Province (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sichuan)
provided plenty natural resources for the development of cooking. The flow of the
Yangtze river (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yangtze)
through Sichuan Province provided nutrients for fundamental foods, spices, and a source of water.
[8] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sichuan_cuisine#cite_note-8)

Reconstructing the theoretical system of modern Sichuan cuisine under the new normal, including the division of the three schools of Sichuan cuisine, On the basis of the established theory of Shanghe Bang, Xiaohe Bang and Xiahe Bang, the standardized and complete expression is:
Shanghe Gang Sichuan cuisine is Rongpai Sichuan cuisine in Chengdu, Leshan-centered areas in the west of Sichuan. Its characteristics are friendly and peaceful, rich in seasoning, relatively light taste, multi-traditional dishes;
[9] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sichuan_cuisine#cite_note-9)
Using spicy bean paste and sugar for flavoring, it is the most widely circulated Sichuan cuisine. Shanghe Bangchuan cuisine is based on traditional classical recipes. It has a mild taste and a long flavor. At the same time, it concentrates on premium government dishes such as royal and official dishes. Delicate and delicate, most of them are traditional Sichuan cuisine that has been handed down for a long time, and it has always been the official cuisine of Sichuan Governor and General Yamen. The overall taste of Shanghe Bang cuisine is rather mild.
[10] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sichuan_cuisine#cite_note-10)
[11] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sichuan_cuisine#cite_note-11)
Xiaohe Bangchuan cuisine is salt gang cuisine centered on Zigong in southern Sichuan, including Yibin cuisine, Luzhou cuisine and Neijiang cuisine, which are characterized by thick taste, heavy taste and rich taste. Characterized by atmospheric, weird, high-end (the reason is salt merchants). Zigong Yanbang dishes are divided into three branches: salt commercial dishes, salt industrial dishes and hall dishes, with spicy taste, Mala taste and sweet and sour taste as three main categories.
[12] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sichuan_cuisine#cite_note-12)
Yanbang dishes are characterized by rich, distinctive and rich taste. The most important thing to pay attention to is the taste of the food.
[13] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sichuan_cuisine#cite_note-13)
Xiahe Bangchuan cuisine is represented by Dazhou cuisine, Chongqing cuisine and Wanzhou cuisine. Together, they form the three main schools of Sichuan cuisine, representing the highest artistic level of Sichuan cuisine development.
[14] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sichuan_cuisine#cite_note-14)
Therefore, Sichuan cuisine has three characteristics: extensive ingredients, diversified flavoring, and strong adaptability to cuisine. It consists of five major categories: banquet dishes, popular side dishes, home-cooked dishes, SanZhengJiuKou dishes,
[15] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sichuan_cuisine#cite_note-15)
flavor snacks and so on to form a complete flavor system.
[16] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sichuan_cuisine#cite_note-16)
Origin theories
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Sichuan_cuisine&action=edit&section=3)
]
Scholars have proposed different theories regarding the division of Sichuan cuisine regions. Wang Dayu introduced in the compilation of Sichuan cuisine history strategy by the Committee on Literature and History of the CPPCC in the whole country: Sichuan cuisine can be roughly divided into Chengdu Bang, Chongqing Bang, Dahe Bang, Xiaohe Bang, from the inside, each has its own special background and representative menu.
[17] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sichuan_cuisine#cite_note-17)
Sichuan cuisine originated in Shu during the Spring and Autumn period and the Warring States period, the beginning of Qin and Han dynasties, and the formation of classical Sichuan cuisine in Han and Jin dynasties. Characterized by Sichuan peppercorn and ginger. In the Tang and Song Dynasties, Sichuan cuisine was developed further, and Sichuan restaurants spread throughout Kaifeng and Lin'an, and won the favor of many diners for their taste characteristics. During the Song dynasty, Sichuan cuisine became an independent cuisine.
Sichuan is rich in products, and natural crops provide abundant raw materials for Sichuan cuisine. Among them, ginger, Sichuan pepper and other seasonings, as early as the Han dynasty, as Sichuan people "like the flavor of spices" characteristics known throughout the country. The taste of Sichuan people today is far from that of
Li Bai (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Li_Bai)
and
Su Shi (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Su_Shi)
. If there were no chili peppers from South America in the Ming and Qing dynasties, it would not be Sichuan cuisine for Sichuan people today. Sichuan cuisine claims to have a history of more than two thousand years. However, it is difficult to say how much Sichuan cuisine is related to ancient Sichuan cuisine. One hard evidence is that before the
Ming (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ming_dynasty)
and
Qing (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qing_dynasty)
dynasties, there were no chili peppers in Sichuan cuisine. During the Ming and Qing dynasties, Sichuan cuisine developed further until the Republic of China. Modern Sichuan cuisine eventually formed the characteristics of "rich variety", "strong taste and spicy", and developed into the first dish of Chinese cuisine.
Chairman Mao (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mao_Zedong)
once said on January 30, 1949, "I believe that a
Chinese medicine (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_medicine)
, a Chinese dish, will be China's two major contributions to the world." This evaluation was repeated in 1953 when he took a nap at the Liuzhuang Hotel in Hangzhou.
Chengdu, the capital of Sichuan Province, was awarded the honorary title of "World Cuisine Capital" by UNESCO in 2010, and only six cities in the world received it. Chengdu Sichuan cuisine has long been the official cuisine of Sichuan Governor and Yamen. Chili peppers were introduced into Sichuan and widely used in Sichuan cuisine, which was a watershed between ancient Sichuan cuisine and modern Sichuan cuisine. Probably during the Kangxi period in the early Qing dynasty. The book "Flower Mirror" written and published by Chen Xiuzi in 1688, Kangxi, is recorded in volume five: "Pepper, a sea mad vine, commonly known as spicy eggplant……the most spicy, used by many people, very fine, winter moon to replace pepper. "Here the paprika, is chili, also known as sea pepper, Qin pepper and so on. The perfect combination of chili peppers and broad beans (i.e., beans) created Sichuan bean, known as the soul of Sichuan cuisine, is widely used in Sichuan cuisine. Peanuts are the most famous of the many varieties of Sichuan Beans. Pixian's is most renowned among the many varieties of Sichuan spicy bean paste. The innovative use of pickled peppers, pickle and black bean sauce in Sichuan cuisine has formed 24 common flavors, 54 cooking methods and more than 3,000 classic traditional dishes in three categories of Sichuan cuisine, which are the hallmarks of modern Sichuan cuisine.
Native to Peru in South America, chili peppers were domesticated as cultivated species in Mexico, introduced to Europe in the 15th century, and introduced from the sea to China in the late 16th century, the late Ming dynasty. Because of the introduction of Western countries, it is also called " Fan pepper". It is also called "sea pepper" because it is introduced from the sea, and Sichuan chili pepper is introduced from Guanzhong to Shu, so it is also called "Qin pepper".
Features
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Sichuan_cuisine&action=edit&section=4)
]
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:MaLaTang.JPG)
Chili
hotpot (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hotpot)
characteristic of Sichuan cuisine
The complex topography of Sichuan Province, including its mountains, hills, plains, plateaus and the
Sichuan Basin (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sichuan_Basin)
, has shaped its food customs with versatile and distinct ingredients.
Abundant rice and vegetables are produced from the fertile Sichuan Basin, whereas a wide variety of herbs, mushrooms and other fungi prosper in the highland regions. Pork is overwhelmingly the most common type of meat consumed.
[5] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sichuan_cuisine#cite_note-Anderson-5)
Beef is somewhat more common in Sichuan cuisine than it is in other Chinese cuisines, perhaps due to the prevalence of oxen in the region.
[18] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sichuan_cuisine#cite_note-18)
Sichuan cuisine also uses various
bovine (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bovine)
and
porcine (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Porcine)
organs as ingredients, such as intestine, arteries, head, tongue, skin and liver, in addition to other commonly used portions of the meat.
Rabbit meat (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rabbit_meat)
is also much more popular in Sichuan than elsewhere in China. It is estimated that the Sichuan Basin and Chongqing area are responsible for about 70 percent of China's total rabbit meat consumption.
[19] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sichuan_cuisine#cite_note-geng-19)
The salt produced from Sichuan
salt springs and wells (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salt_in_Chinese_history)
, unlike sea salt, does not contain iodine, which led to
goiter (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goiter)
problems before the 20th century.
[5] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sichuan_cuisine#cite_note-Anderson-5)
Sichuan cuisine often contains food preserved through
pickling (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pickling)
,
salting (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salting_(food))
and
drying (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Drying_(food))
. Preserved dishes are generally served as spicy dishes with heavy application of chili oil.
Meal styles
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Sichuan_cuisine&action=edit&section=5)
]
The most unique and important spice in Sichuan cuisine is the
Sichuan (Szechuan) pepper (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sichuan_pepper)
(
花椒
;
huājiāo
; 'flower pepper'), which has an intense, fragrant citruslike taste and produces a notably distinct "numbingly spicy" (
麻
;
má
) sensation in the mouth. Other commonly used spices in Sichuan cuisine are
garlic (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Garlic)
,
chili peppers (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chili_pepper)
,
ginger (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ginger)
, and
star anise (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star_anise)
. There are 40 kinds of Sichuan cuisine cooking techniques such as frying, stir fry, oiling, and crispy fried. Taste type to spicy, fish flavor, strange taste as its outstanding characteristics.
[20] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sichuan_cuisine#cite_note-20)
Broad bean chili paste (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doubanjiang)
(
豆瓣醬
;
dòubànjiàng
) is one of the most important seasonings.
[5] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sichuan_cuisine#cite_note-Anderson-5)
It is an essential component to famous dishes such as Mapo tofu and twice-cooked pork. Sichuan cuisine is the origin of several prominent sauces/flavors widely used in modern
Chinese cuisine (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_cuisine)
, including:
Yuxiang (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yuxiang)
(魚香)
Mala (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sichuan_mala)
(麻辣)
Guaiwei (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guaiwei)
(怪味)
Other examples of mixed flavors including spicy and hot (
Mala (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sichuan_mala)
),
fish flavor (
Yuxiang (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yuxiang)
), hot and sour, the five spices (
Wuxiang (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Five-spice_powder)
;
五香),
ginger (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ginger)
juice, mashed
garlic (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Garlic)
,
sweet and sour (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sweet_and_sour)
, spice salt (
Jiaoyan
; 椒鹽), dried
tangerine (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tangerine)
or
orange (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orange_(fruit))
peel (
Chenpi
; 陳皮), burnt chili, pot-stewed fowl (
Lu
; 滷味), odd flavor (
Guaiwei
; 怪味), and other recombinations of these seasonings.
[21] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sichuan_cuisine#cite_note-21)
Common preparation techniques in Sichuan cuisine include
stir frying (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stir_frying)
,
steaming (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steaming)
and
braising (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Braising)
, but a complete list would include more than 20 distinct techniques.

### Do Not Sell or Share My Personal Data

When you visit our website, we store cookies on your browser to collect information. The information collected might relate to you, your preferences or your device, and is mostly used to make the site work as you expect it to and to provide a more personalized web experience. However, you can choose not to allow certain types of cookies, which may impact your experience of the site and the services we are able to offer. Click on the different category headings to find out more and change our default settings according to your preference. You cannot opt-out of our First Party Strictly Necessary Cookies as they are deployed in order to ensure the proper functioning of our website (such as prompting the cookie banner and remembering your settings, to log into your account, to redirect you when you log out, etc.). For more information about the First and Third Party Cookies used please follow this link. 

[More information](https://cookiepedia.co.uk/giving-consent-to-cookies)

#### Strictly Necessary Cookies

Always Active

Title: Chinese-Style Tender Braised Chicken with Potatoes {New & Improved Recipe!}

URL Source: https://www.foodelicacy.com/braised-chicken-with-potatoes/%22,

Published Time: 2020-04-23T05:50:00+00:00

Markdown Content:
[Home](https://www.foodelicacy.com/) / [Main Ingredient](https://www.foodelicacy.com/ingredient/) / [Chicken](https://www.foodelicacy.com/ingredient/chicken/) / Chinese-Style Tender Braised Chicken with Potatoes {New & Improved Recipe!}

_Braised chicken with potatoes is quintessential Chinese comfort food. Hearty, wholesome and delicious, it is easy to cook up and easily becomes a family favourite. Enjoy juicy, tender chicken and butter-soft potatoes soaked in a thick, tasty umami gravy over steamed rice._

I was poring through my older posts and this **tender braised chicken with potatoes** is a hot favourite, even today. But I have to admit, guys, I almost cringed at the photos I took back then!

There were so many things wrong with the photos, I didn’t know where to start! Tone, composition, lighting, staging, basically the whole nine yards just _ughhh_! Goodness, I really didn’t do this dish any justice!

Finally, I’m putting things right. This [circuit breaker](https://www.timeout.com/singapore/things-to-do/things-you-need-to-know-about-singapores-circuit-breaker-measures) we’re into might just have given me the opportunity and time to rejuvenate some of my oldest recipes.

Yup, finally throwing a little bit of love and attention wherever I can. So, let’s take a new look, and I mean this literally, at this amazing dish of Chinese-style braised chicken with potatoes!

![Image 1: Chinese-Style Tender Braised Chicken with Potatoes](blob:http://localhost/77696830d579faf78ab8e4b0bbfbe6ef)

Let me just say this. I am such a fan of gravy and sauces that I often look to Cantonese food for a lot of inspiration in my cooking.

All is well because my hubby and I both happen to love Cantonese cuisine. So in that way, our palettes are congruent which makes my task of preparing our family meals so much easier.

About Cantonese braised chicken
-------------------------------

Now, you probably have some impression of how famous the Cantonese are for their food. Travel to Hong Kong, and nearby Guangzhou, and you’ll be totally wowed by the amazing and tantalising smorgasboard of Canton cuisine.

Not only for preparing elegant and exquisite dishes fit for banquets and feasts, but also for a great variety of simple, hearty home-cooked meals. And this braised chicken with potatoes is one such homey dish.

![Image 2: Tender braised chicken with potatoes](blob:http://localhost/c08f08fb29c8f26e9b89ad3de8583b61)

Every Chinese family has their cherished recipes for braised chicken. In fact, you won’t usually find this on a typical Chinese restaurant menu. That’s why we treasure the instances, and memories of when our mothers cooked this for us with love and dedication.

Now, this chicken with potatoes dish has delicate but distinct flavours. How it tastes is ultimately defined by the combination of seasonings used.

However, it’s easy to go overboard with seasonings, especially the sauces and that’s not ideal. Otherwise, the whole dish will lose the little nuances of flavour and will taste overwhelmingly of the sauce.

Ingredients for the dish
------------------------

The great thing about this is that it takes a pretty short list of ingredients to cook up this hearty wholesome dish. You’re likely to have all of this in your pantry right now. So here’s what we will need:

![Image 3: Tender braised chicken with potatoes](blob:http://localhost/c08f08fb29c8f26e9b89ad3de8583b61)

*   **chicken**
*   **potatoes**
*   **ginger**
*   **garlic**
*   **spring onions**
*   **Asian sauces** – oyster sauce, light soy sauce and dark soy sauce
*   **Chinese wine**
*   **sesame oil**

### Tips on chicken cuts and potato variety

*   **Choose the mix of chicken cuts you like**. My favourite options for braising are either _a whole chicken cut up_, or tastier cuts like _chicken thighs_, _drumsticks_, and of course, _chicken wings_. Who doesn’t love wings, right?
*   **Skin-on is more tasty than skin off**.If you want more flavour, skin-on chicken parts are better as the oils will infuse with the braising sauce. 
*   **Granola potatoes** are, in my humble opinion, the best variety to use for braising. But, basically any waxy white or yellow potatoes that hold their shape well when boiled. Other suitable options are _**Yukon Gold**_ and _**Fingerling**_ potatoes.

These are just my suggestions, of course and nothing should stop you from enjoying this dish with the chicken cuts and potatoes you love to eat. So, if you’re all for skinless breast meat and potatoes mashed and literally dissolved in your gravy, then enjoy!

![Image 4: Tender braised chicken with potatoes](blob:http://localhost/c08f08fb29c8f26e9b89ad3de8583b61)

Step-by-step cooking: braised chicken with potatoes
---------------------------------------------------

Before we even fire up the stove, go ahead and marinate the chicken with the seasonings. The meat has to sit for at least an hour. Preferably, if you’re planning to cook ahead, an overnight marinate in the chiller would be even better.

*   **Step 1: Deep-fry potatoes until lightly browned**. Heat up 1/2 cup of oil in a wok or skillet over medium heat. Once the oil is very hot, deep fry the potato chunks until they turn light brown. Turn over the potatoes as needed to brown all sides evenly. When done, remove with a slotted spoon and set aside.

*   **Step 2: Fry the aromatics and chicken**. Scoop out the oil, leaving behind 3 tbsp. When the oil is hot again, fry the aromatics (ginger and spring onions) over high heat until fragrant. 

*   **Step 3: Add the whole garlic cloves**, and toss for 30 seconds.

*   **Steps 4 & 5: Put in the seasoned chicken**. Sear over high heat till lightly browned**.**

![Image 5](blob:http://localhost/c425303b0eed4fd9ed506c95372dd7e1)![Image 6](blob:http://localhost/c425303b0eed4fd9ed506c95372dd7e1)![Image 7](blob:http://localhost/c425303b0eed4fd9ed506c95372dd7e1)![Image 8](blob:http://localhost/c425303b0eed4fd9ed506c95372dd7e1)![Image 9](blob:http://localhost/c425303b0eed4fd9ed506c95372dd7e1)![Image 10](blob:http://localhost/c425303b0eed4fd9ed506c95372dd7e1)![Image 11](blob:http://localhost/c425303b0eed4fd9ed506c95372dd7e1)![Image 12](blob:http://localhost/3ae4d04f916712e5394829daa66ef1f5)
*   **Step 6: Add water and let braise.** There should be enough water to just cover the chicken. Let the mixture come to a boil, then reduce the heat until a gentle simmer. Let braise, uncovered, for 30 minutes.

*   **Step 7: Put in fried potatoes**. Halfway through the braising, stir in the fried potato chunks. If the water has reduced too quickly, add more water as needed to braise the potatoes. Stir occasionally, but be careful not to break up the potatoes.

*   **Step 8: Braise until meat is tender and reduce to thicken gravy.** Once the meat is tender to your liking, taste the gravy and season to your tastes. If you love your gravy thick, simmer to further reduce but bear in mind, the flavours will intensify. So if it was just salty enough, it will taste saltier if you reduce further. Alternatively, you can also thicken the gravy by thickening with corn starch solution.

*   [Soy Sauce Chicken](https://www.foodelicacy.com/soy-sauce-chicken/)
*   [Three Cup Chicken – Tasty Treasure of Taiwan](https://www.foodelicacy.com/three-cup-chicken/)

Braised Chicken with Potatoes
-----------------------------

[![Image 13](blob:http://localhost/2397d1366f84c41288c148c7050a4723)](https://www.foodelicacy.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/chicken-with-potatoes-2A-scaled.jpg)

4.7 from 37 reviews

This is a quintessential Chinese comfort dish of braised chicken with potatoes. Juicy, tender chicken with butter-soft potatoes basking in a thick savoury gravy flavoured with the juices of chicken, oyster sauce, soy sauce, Chinese wine and sesame oil.

Hands Free Mode Prevent screen from sleeping

*   ▢  800 gm chicken thighs and wings
*   ▢  4 potatoes
*   ▢  1 thumb-length ginger knob
*   ▢  2 stalks spring onions
*   ▢  6 whole garlic cloves skin on
*   ▢  Corn starch solution for thickening optional

#### Seasonings

*   ▢  1 tsp salt
*   ▢  2 tbsp oyster sauce
*   ▢  2 tsp light soy sauce
*   ▢  2 tsp thick dark soy sauce
*   ▢  1 tbsp Chinese wine
*   ▢  1 tbsp sesame oil
*   ▢  1 tsp sugar or more as needed
*   ▢  Salt and ground pepper to taste

*   Wash and pat dry chicken parts. In a mixing bowl, combine chicken and seasonings. Coat evenly all over and set aside, covered with cling wrap, for 1 hour.

*   Peel potatoes and slice into quarters. Peel and slice ginger thinly. Cut spring onions into thumb-length sections.

*   Heat up a wok or skillet over high heat. Add ½ cup of oil. When very hot, fry potato chunks. While frying, turn potatoes as needed to lightly brown all sides. Remove with a slotted spoon and set aside.

*   Remove the oil, leaving behind 3 tbsp.

*   When oil is hot again, fry ginger and spring onions until fragrant, about 30 seconds. Add garlic cloves and fry for 15 seconds. Put in seasoned chicken and stir fry to brown the meat all over, about 3 to 4 minutes.

*   Add enough water to cover the chicken. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat until a gentle simmer. Let braise, uncovered, for 30 minutes.

*   Halfway through the braising, add fried potatoes. Stir in gently, and add more water if needed. Stir occasionally to braise the potatoes evenly, be careful not to break them up.

*   Once chicken is tender and potatoes are soft, taste the gravy and season with salt and pepper to taste.

*   Simmer a bit longer to reduce if you want a thicker gravy and more intense flavour. Alternatively, if you want more gravy, thicken with corn starch solution to your desired consistency.

*   When done, dish out into serving dish. Garnish with sliced spring onions and serve.
